AMERICAN POLITICAL PRINCIPLES AND THE WAR
Dr. A. C. MILLSPAUGH,Instructor in Political Science
Article Ill.
The righteousness of our war
with Germany and Austria is at
this date beyond argument, but the
principles for which we are fighting need constant study and clarification as the war progresses. We
became a belligerent, as President
Wilson has said, with no special
grievance of our own and with no
selfish purposes. But while we are
fighting to make possible a British victory and a French victory
we are not fighting for these ends
alone. We are fighting now for a
clean-cut American victory—a victory that, translated into peace
terms, will mean a distinct and
permanent gain for America and
Americanism. This gain is not to
be represented by annexations, indemnities or commercial privileges; but by the definite worldwide expansion of the sphere of
influence of American political
ideals.
These ideals or principles may
be variously stated, but they are
at least three: The supremacy of
law, governmental responsibility
to public opinion, and federalism.
These principles are a part of our
experiment in government, lacking any one of them America
would lose its political identity,
and their extension will mean
more to our future security, prosperity, self-respect and power than
any material acquisitions could
possibly mean.
In America our various governments are subject to definite legal
and constitutional limitations;
our officials, from the President
down, derive their powers only
from the written law; no official
can long act arbitrarily; and the
military is strictly subordinate to
the civil power. Law is sovereign.
Our government, furthermore,
is based on the consent of the governed and on the belief that everything possible should be done by
means of a universal and liberal
education and unrestricted discussion so that the formation of public opinion may be intelligent and
free, and its action on the government, through political parties
or other agencies, quick, direct
and decisive.
Federalism is a system of organization, by means of which
self-governing provinces or states
may exist within a unified nation.

At the monthly meeting of the
Hopkins Circle of the Omicron
Delta Kappa, held on Monday,
December 17, at the Hopkins Club
and preceded by a dinner, Dr.
Robert B. Holliston, associate professor of German, was initiated
into the society as a faculty member. Reports were submitted at
the business session of the meeting by the chairmen of the "prep"
school campaign and the service
flag committees.
Dr. Roulston, the faculty initiate of the 0. D. K., is a dyed-inthe-wool Hopkins man; he received his A.B. here in 1900, and
his Ph.D. in 1906, and is now associate professor of German in the
University. He has served as a
member of the baseball advisory
committee for several years, and
has recently been appointed managing editor of the Alumni Magazine. He is thoroughly interested
in all the activities—undergraduate especially—of the university,
and is one of the most popular
men at Homewood.
In accepting his election to the
society Dr. Roulston heartily indorsed the work of the 0. D. K.,
and paid a great tribute to the
1917 football team, which, despite untold handicaps, made a remarkable showing and set a high
standard for Hopkins war-time
teams.
The "prep" school campaign
committee has sent out questionnaires to the principals of the various State schools, and will soon
follow the policy of last year by
sending speakers to expound the
countless benefits of dear old Hopkins.
A committee is now investigating the number of Hopkins men
in the service for the University
eservice flag, which the 0. D. K.
will present to the University in
the near future.

With the annual theater party
and banquet, when Carl Schmidt,
'19, was elected to lead the 1918
eleven, on Thursday, December
20th, football at Johns Hopkins
for the season of 1917 was laid to
rest amid joy and merry-making.
Promptly at 8 o'clock the entire
squad of players,coaches and managers assembled at the Maryland
Theater and tramped in to see the
vaudeville supreme. Helped on by
timely remarks from the J. H. U.
audience (the most timely of
which were from "Eagle Beak"
Jones) the show was passable, and
all adjourned to the Rennert Hotel after two and one-half hours of
decided pleasure.
Arrived at the Rennert—that
hotel renowned the world over for
noise and life (?)—the men sat
down around the board at something the hotel is famous for,,
good food. With stomachs full
and all feeling very comfortable
amid the anatomy, Captain Woodward called the assemblage to order by trying out the steel of his
knife on a china plate. Speeches
followed in rapid-fire order:
Coach Brennick, Alec Wolfe, McKeithen, Captain Primrose, of the
1915 championship team; Nicodemus, of Frederick fame, and
others contributed with talks on
the season and the results obtained. All agreed that the Black
and Blue had taken great strides
forward and in the right direction
during the season just closed, and
predicted greater timings in the
years to come. Captain Woodward
heartily thanked the men for their
interest and co-operation, and, although expecting to leave college
soon to accept a commission in
the Navy, pointed out that his
heart and interests will always be
with the Black and Blue.
Speechmaking out of the way,
the men turned their attention to
the choice of a captain for 1918.
Schmidt, veteran lineman for
three years, and Stanley, all-Maryland guard the past season, were
nominated .-for the position of
honor. After a spirited election
Schmidt was awarded that final
goal of all college football players,
and responded with a speech, in
which he promised to give all he
had to the University and her
team. After a series of spirited
hullabaloos the meeting adjourned
and a very pleasant evening was
brought to a close.

At a meeting of time Johns Hopkins Philological Association on
Friday, December 21, Dr. John C.
French, associateprofessor of English, read a paper on "Poe and the
Baltimore Saturday risiter," ill
which he told of his discovery of
several unpublished poems of Edgar Allan Poe, the Baltimore poet.
At the same meeting Dr. Maurice
Bloomfield, professor of Sanskrit
and comparative philology, read a
paper on his recently published
work, "Rig-Veda Repetition."
Dr. Henry Wood, president of
the association, called the meeting
to order at 11.30 A. M. The minutes of the previous meeting were
read by Dr. Robinsin, and approved.
Dr. Haupt presented a minor
communication. Dr. French and
Dr. Bloomfield were congratulated
by the president and other members of the society on their work
of which they told in their papers.
Dr. French has kindly consented to write for THE NEWSLETTER a brief account of his discovery, and to the publication of
one of the poems,"The Serenade."
It is interesting to note that the
discovery of the poems grew out
of one of the courses in English
literature. The account follows:
"The most significant event in
the literary life of Edgar Allan
Poe was his success in what would
HOW be called a short-story contest, instituted by a Baltimore
weekly paper in the summer of
1833. At this time Poe was living
in obscurity with relatives in
Baltimore. He had published
three slender volumes of verse,
had rejected opportunitiesfor a military career, and, being now hopelessly estranged from Mr. Allen,
had tried in vain to find congenial
employment. When the Baltimore
Saturday lisiter offered a prize
of $50 for the best tale and $25 for
the best short poem, Poe submitted manuscripts forboth prizes.
Thejudges awarded him the larger
prize without hesitation, and apparently would have given him the
other prize also if they had not
thought it undesirable for one
competitor to receive both. One
of these judges was John P. Kennedy, already ivell known as an
author. He became at once Poe's
friend and adviser, secured him
the editorship of the Southern Literary Messenger, and rescued him
from the despair that might well
have prevented him from leading
a literary life.

"The paper that was able to do
Poe such a valuable service was
established in 1831 by Mr. Charles
F. Cloud, previously editor of the
L'llaws. Press. It was not a newspaper, but a literary weekly. Until recently no file of the Visiter
was known to Poe editors, and it
was supposed that none had...survived. Bound copies of the paper
had, however, been preserved by
relatives of the proprietor. All
but one of the volumes were destroyed by fire, and by a curious
and fortunate coincidence it was
the volume for 1833 that escaped.
This volume has now, by the courtesy of its owners, been made available to students of Poe. Besides
the announcements of the prize
contest and of the award and the
list of Poe's successful tale, "MS.
Found in a Bottle" and his poem,
"The Coliseum," it contains a
hitherto unpublished poem by Poe
and two poems signed with the
pseudonym Tamerlane which are
also very probably by'
Poe.
"The acknowledged poem appeared in the issue of April 20,
1833, several weeks before the first
announcement of the Visiter's
prize offer. "It is as follows:
SERE NADE.—By E. A. Poe.
So sweet the hour, so calm the time,
I feel it more than half a crime
When Nature sleeps and stars are
mute,
To mar the silence ev'n with lute.
At rest on ocean's brilliant dies
An image of Elysium lies:
Seven Pleiades entranced in Heaven,
Form in the deep another seven:
Endymion nodding from above
Sees in the sea a second love. .
Within the valleys dim and brown,
And on the spectral mountain's
crown
The wearied light is dying down
And earth, and stars, and sea, and
sky
Are redolent of sleep, as I
Am redolent of -thee and thine
Enthralling love, my Adeline.
But list, 0 list—so soft and low
Thy lover's voice tonight shall flow
That scarce awake thy soul shall
deem
My words the music of a dream.
Thus, while no single sound too rude,
Upon thy slumber shall intrude,
Our thoughts, our souls-0 God
above!
In every deed shall mingle, love.

As is necessity the mother of invention so also is war the mother
of sacrifice. In sacrificing the
traditional victory bonfire on Old
South Mountain, Lehigh has once
more come to the foreground in
doing her bit to help the Government in these critical times. It
is highly commendable that not a
dissenting voice was heard at yesterday's college meeting, when it
was definitely decided to give up
one of Lehigh's most cherished
traditions in order to further the
nation-wide campaign of the Government against unnecessary
waste. As was pointed out by
President Drinker in his short
talk to the college body, the waste
of wood itself is negligible. It is
the principle and example to others
which is the main factor, and the
action taken will without doubt
stand as a fitting exaMple to the
entire community. — From The
Brown and White, Lehigh.

The Johns Hopkins Independent basket-ball team was defeated
by the crack quint of the Naval
Academy by the score of 53- to 5
on Wednesday, December 19.
Lack of condition was the chief
cause of the overwhelming defeat
at the hands of the Navy basketers. Although the score appears one-sided, the game was
interesting and hotly contested,
especialy during the first half.
Hopkins started off with a
rush; they kept the Annapolis lads
from scoring for about five minutes by their excellent defense
work, but they themselves were
unable to gather any points. Then
Welch, of the Navy five, caged a
foul goal, and a few minutes later
Captain Allen, of the Navy,scored
one from the field.
But the home team was not destined to hold this lead very long,

goals of the game. Hopkins, at
this period of the game, was playing the fast and heavy Navy team
to a standstill. A few minutes
later Kennedy caged another very
difficult basket, and the score was
4 to 3 in Hopkins favor.
Hopkins maintained this lead
for several minutes, and the hundreds of ensigns, who packed all
four sides of the court, shouted
for Hopkins and then begged
their team to get started. Very
soon another goal was caged by
the Navy, and they were once more
out in front, but the score was
tied a few seconds later when
"Doc" Love succeded in caging a
free throw from the foul circle.
This ended Hopkins scoring for
the first half and for the whole
game. The team, being in poor
condition, could not stand the
strain, and Navy had everything
her own way from this time on.
A long string of field goals and
foul goals were made immediately
after this by the Navy forwards,
and the first halt ended, 25 to 5,
in favor of the midshipmen.
The second half was a repetition of the latter part of the first,
the ensigns making 28 points in
this perioad, while Hopkins could
not even get a single foul goal.
Navy sent in their substitutes in
the last five minutes, and a few
seconds later Hopkins followed
suit. The Navy subs managed to
add a few points to their total,
while the second string men of
the Independents could not score
at all. The game ended 53 to 5 in
favor of the Naval Academy.

Prof. A. G. Christie, of the department of mechanical engineering, outlined to a number of the
foremost business men in Baltimore, assembled at the Hotel Emerson under the auspices of the
Merchants and Manufacturers' Association on Friday, December 28,
some specific methods of saving
fuel on a large scale—a scale
ranging in some instances as high
as 20 per cent. of the total fuel
consumption.
Professor Christie told them
how they could eliminate the
wasteful use of heat, how they
could equip their boilers to do
more efficient work, and how they
could obtain the voluntary co-operation of their firemen.
As for the business men themselves he told them to put on
heavy underwear.
"Your minds will work much
better," he said, "if you will cut
down the temperature of your offices to 68 degrees. The favorite
temperature in offices in this city
now seems to be about 75 degrees.
By cutting this down and by putting on heavy underwear you will
find yourself doing better work
and saving one-sixth of your heat."
One of the first things to do in
the factories, Professor Christie
asserted, was to cover all pipes
and boilers with asbestos. Further, he advised cutting off heat
from rooms in which it is not
needed; keeping doors closed; turning off heat and light when leaving the office; eliminating most of
the heat in hallways, which comprise about 10 per cent, of office
building space; providing engineers and firemen with instruments that will help them in conserving fuel; and paying firemen
bonuses for savings effected.
Profesor Christie also urged an
intensive campaign that would acquaint- everyone with workable
methods for saving coal.

Dr. A. C. MILLSPAUGH,Instructor in Political Science

The righteousness of our war
with Germany and Austria is at

Wilson has said, with no special

selfish purposes. But while we are
fighting to make possible a British victory and a French victory

clean-cut American victory—a victory that, translated into peace
terms, will mean a distinct and
permanent gain for America and
Americanism. This gain is not to
be represented by annexations, indemnities or commercial privileges; but by the definite worldwide expansion of the sphere of
influence of American political
ideals.
These ideals or principles may
be variously stated, but they are
at least three: The supremacy of
law, governmental responsibility
to public opinion, and federalism.
These principles are a part of our
experiment in government, lacking any one of them America
would lose its political identity,
and their extension will mean
more to our future security, prosperity, self-respect and power than
any material acquisitions could
possibly mean.

Hopkins Independent Basket-ball Team
Defeated by Navy 53 to 5 Hopkins
Makes Good Start, But Finds
Going Too Rough.

The Johns Hopkins Independent basket-ball team was defeated
by the crack quint of the Naval
Academy by the score of 53- to 5
on Wednesday, December 19.
Lack of condition was the chief
cause of the overwhelming defeat
at the hands of the Navy basketers. Although the score appears one-sided, the game was
interesting and hotly contested,
especialy during the first half.
Hopkins started off with a
rush; they kept the Annapolis lads
from scoring for about five minutes by their excellent defense
work, but they themselves were
unable to gather any points. Then
Welch, of the Navy five, caged a
foul goal, and a few minutes later
Captain Allen, of the Navy,scored
one from the field.
But the home team was not destined to hold this lead very long,
for, after "Doc" Love had missed
a foul shot, Kennedy got-the ball
and made one of the prettiest field
goals of the game. Hopkins, at
this period of the game, was playing the fast and heavy Navy team
to a standstill. A few minutes
later Kennedy caged another very
difficult basket, and the score was
4 to 3 in Hopkins favor.
Hopkins maintained this lead
for several minutes, and the hundreds of ensigns, who packed all
four sides of the court, shouted
for Hopkins and then begged
their team to get started. Very
soon another goal was caged by
the Navy, and they were once more
out in front, but the score was
tied a few seconds later when
"Doc" Love succeded in caging a
free throw from the foul circle.
This ended Hopkins scoring for
the first half and for the whole
game. The team, being in poor
condition, could not stand the
strain, and Navy had everything
her own way from this time on.
A long string of field goals and
foul goals were made immediately
after this by the Navy forwards,
and the first halt ended, 25 to 5,
in favor of the midshipmen.
The second half was a repetition of the latter part of the first,
the ensigns making 28 points in
this perioad, while Hopkins could
not even get a single foul goal.
Navy sent in their substitutes in
the last five minutes, and a few
seconds later Hopkins followed
suit. The Navy subs managed to
add a few points to their total,
while the second string men of
the Independents could not score
at all. The game ended 53 to 5 in
favor of the Naval Academy.

Prof. A. G. Christie, of the department of mechanical engineering, outlined to a number of the
foremost business men in Baltimore, assembled at the Hotel Emerson under the auspices of the
Merchants and Manufacturers' Association on Friday, December 28,
some specific methods of saving
fuel on a large scale—a scale
ranging in some instances as high
as 20 per cent. of the total fuel
consumption.
Professor Christie told them
how they could eliminate the
wasteful use of heat, how they
could equip their boilers to do
more efficient work, and how they
could obtain the voluntary co-operation of their firemen.
As for the business men themselves he told them to put on
heavy underwear.
"Your minds will work much
better," he said, "if you will cut
down the temperature of your offices to 68 degrees. The favorite
temperature in offices in this city
now seems to be about 75 degrees.
By cutting this down and by putting on heavy underwear you will
find yourself doing better work
and saving one-sixth of your heat."
One of the first things to do in
the factories, Professor Christie
asserted, was to cover all pipes
and boilers with asbestos. Further, he advised cutting off heat
from rooms in which it is not
needed; keeping doors closed; turning off heat and light when leaving the office; eliminating most of
the heat in hallways, which comprise about 10 per cent, of office
building space; providing engineers and firemen with instruments that will help them in conserving fuel; and paying firemen
bonuses for savings effected.
Profesor Christie also urged an
intensive campaign that would acquaint- everyone with workable
methods for saving coal.
